author: {'steamid': '76561198074041475', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1007, 'last_played': 1520249352}
review:
Giga Wrecker is a rather interesting game developed by Game Freak, who seem to make new standalone games when they presumably get bored of creating new Pokemon titles. Despite the fact that Giga Wrecker is obviously not the main focus of the developer, the game is of high quality, and blends together action and puzzle platforming elements quite well.

(+) The debris system is simple to understand yet fun to use. Defeat enemies to get debris, and use that to defeat bigger enemies/ access new areas. It reminds me a little bit of the multiple Kirby system from Kirby Mass Attack, which was another game I quite enjoyed.
(+) The action elements are basic and the puzzle elements aren't the most challenging, but both complement each other very well to make a great experience.
(+) I didn't encounter any major bugs
(+) Physics, especially for the flying debris, are pretty realistic for a cartoony platformer
(+) Large non-linear upgrade tree, which is great for completionists like me, but isn't necessary for beating the game
(+) Many optional puzzle rooms which reward the player for completing them with extra XP, or new skins for weapons (instead of just being paid DLC, thank goodness)
(+) I absolutely LOVED this game's artstyle (I actually use the screenshots I took of this game as my laptop screensaver), but of course  whether you like it or not depends on your personal preference.
(+) Background music was nothing spectacular, but good enough that I didn't feel the need to mute it and play other songs over it

(-) Story is so-so, it didn't really make me care about any of the characters except for the protagonist
(-) Boss battles were pretty easy once you figure out the attack pattern. Only the final boss was somewhat challenging. However, this problem is partially resolved with the post-game Boss Rush mode
(-) Not a very long game. I completed the story and got all the achievements in under 17 hours.
(-) Using a controller to play is almost a necessity in my opinion. 

Overall, I really enjoyed playing this game. Definitely worth picking up if you are a fan of platformers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030791854', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1532876137}
review:
Pros:
-Gorgeous graphics
-Challenging puzzles that don't punish the player when they inevitbly mess up
-Fun metroidvania feel
-Level design that usually(but not always) lets the player stop and think before jumping into the fray
-Variety of tools available to the player both in and out of combat
-Interesting setting and amusing characters

Cons:
-Controls not always quite as responsive as you'd like
-Without spoiling naything, the story is relatively weak

author: {'steamid': '76561198058511775', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1073, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1073, 'last_played': 1517174876}
review: Giga Wrecker is a kinda adventure game with jump'n'run and platform elements where you also use some physical aspects to go through the game. In the game you can somehow destroy the environment and you got the ability to gather debris which you can use it to your advantage for example like forming a lock / square / dice where you can jump on it, so you can reach places that are normally too high for you. Or using the debris to form a blade to cut something or attacking enemies with increased range. These are some possiblities you can do and there are more of them. Also there is some kind of a skill-tree so you can upgrade abilities by passing some time in game when you got enough exp / materials. The riddles are pretty fun to solve some of them are easier and some of them are more difficult. But one of the most important thing is the timing because I mentioned before that you use physical elements / aspects in this game and at many points of this game you need to hit the right moment to surpass lots of the riddles. If you failed to hit the perfect timing don't worry because in every area with a riddle there is a sphere / orb which you can trigger to reset the area. And there are also some bossfights. I have to say the bossfights are in the beginning pretty challenging and rough but also pretty fun. Also the story is well made and kinda profound. All in all I think Giga Wrecker is a pretty fun game and it's worth to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198414362409', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2343, 'last_played': 1579391718}
review:
A fantastic game and overall great experience.

You may have to do trial and error with the physics engine but the physics in this game is really what sets it apart from others. The characters are nice, good soundtrack and while short the sci-fi futuristic orientanted story was good.

The downside? I wish the game was longer! Hopefully Game Freak can find the time to produce more, I'm still waiting for the new playable character update to put even more hours into GIGA WRECKER.

TL;DR: Great, solid game that proves yet again that GAME FREAK aren't just about PokÃ©mon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013728629', 'num_games_owned': 307, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 999, 'last_played': 1528041490}
review: Fun metroidvania game, especially if you're a fan of the anime style graphics. Lots of puzzles with multiple solutions mean that even once you unlock new abilities moving forward isn't always easy. The soundtrack wasn't super memorable which is a shame, but figuring out the boss mechanics was pretty enjoyable so I enjoyed it overall. I don't think the game has much replay value either but it was still a good game. There's far worse things you could spend your money on, so I'd give it an 8.5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975973970', 'num_games_owned': 501, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1520997500}
review:
The game is broken on a wide variety of systems (particularly if you have a monitor above 1080p).   Beyond that? The devs don't really care.   Look at this thread where I reported my issues ( http://steamcommunity.com/app/454410/discussions/0/1457328819912207243/ )  

You might think at first "Oh, looks like a reasonable exchange"

No, look at the dates.   First response?  Two weeks.   I didn't notice a reply, but they were nice enough to follow-up.... a full month later. With more questions despite already having indepth system information. 

If the game runs fine, keep it.  But if you have ANY technical problems? Refund.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043728918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 291, 'playtime_forever': 2054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2054, 'last_played': 1518329548}
review:
Gamefreak is at their best when Nintendo allows them to stop making Pokemon games for a split second. Drill Dozer is the earliest game I can remember them making other than Pokemon; its like the employees were set loose for a bit and made something they wanted to. The game was well produced with a lot of charm and creativity in its use of its central game mechanic. Tembo the Badass Elephant was another surprise; creatively different but just as good.

With Giga Wrecker I see a pattern: Gamefreak is really good at making creative titles. As was the case with the other games, Wrecker focuses on a central game mechanic and delves deep to flesh it out for as many game possibilities as possible. 

The premise is that every piece of rubble, from enemies to walls, can be 'sucked in' to form a ball you carry around that can be used to clobber enemies and the environment. You can use all this debris to form javelins that stick to walls, rockets that chomp away at whatever is in front of them, or a cube you can use as a platform. Most of the challenge comes from using your abilities to get through rooms-this is the puzzle element of the game and the 'meat' of the title.

The terrain that you do break and enemy leftovers on the field leave debris which can be used as a platform and which moves freely on the ground. Later on wiring and a light, poisenous gas is introduced which can be torn from platforms causing them to move and lift said platforms, respectively. This forms the 'physics' aspect of the puzzles.

It's done pretty well and I've never been stuck on some BS puzzle that infuriated me or made use of the physics engine in such a way that you only get it right half the time. In a way the physics are a bit of a red herring: if you look at any walkthrough if you do what they do you will get the same results. There is no need to balance a beam on your forehead or obsessively press back and forth on your pad in order to guide a wire through a needle. Which means that with some puzzles you might 'feel' like you can get something going because you can move the platform and everything around you so much, but typically the answers are much simpler.

I believe its worth noting how amazing the translation is. And by amazing I mean its Google Translate, which admiteddly still gets the message across and isn't that bad, but damn. I feel as if some of the plot elements were lost in translation. Which is a bit of a shame since this is obviously meant to segueway into a possible sequel since they built up a world and left the ending on one of those, "we've defeated the menace but there is still work to be done" notes. The writing equivalent of "keep your hopes up but we're probably not getting a sequel". Point is they laid enough of a foundation in the writing to make more come of it in the future, but not so much to commit themselves to a sequel.

Oh, and shout outs to the man Shinji Hosoe, known for his musical compositions on the Zero Escape series. He worked on the soundtrack for this game and man is it obvious in some songs. He has a certain musical style that is uniquely his; it was good enough for me to purchase the OST seperately. 

Recommended; more unique, good games from Game Freak please. Because of that I won't complain too much about the translation. Definitely purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006005209', 'num_games_owned': 2549, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1202, 'last_played': 1515172149}
review:
This game is made from the creators of PokÃ©mon games, Game Freak Inc., but it has nothing to do with PokÃ©mon. The game is a [b]platformer/puzzle game[/b] with interesting mechanics of using debris from broken blocks or enemies to your advantage, by transforming it into blocks, javelins, sword, shooting it or just using it to break stuff, move stuff, made stuff work and destroy your enemies. Your enemies are a race of Ajeets, which are like robots who attacked your world, killed everyone and got control of all they could, using humans as subjects or just work force.

I think to me one of the strongest points of the game were the [b]artstyle, the story and the mechanics[/b]. The [b]artstyle[/b] seems very unique with a cyberpunk theme, and I really like how all the stages and especially characters are drawn, the main characters and the bosses look incredible. The [b]battles[/b] between you and the bosses are very enjoyable. The [b]story[/b] is very unpredictable and goes to unexpected routes, when you just think things were over or were too simple. The physics are very interesting. And the soundtrack is ok, it has nothing really special here. 

The [b]physics[/b] may give you many options on how to solve a puzzle, sometimes making it easier or a little harder,  there are enemies, lasers, moving platforms, shooting lasers, etc. They are not really random like some people mentioned in other reviews(mostly people who didn't beat the game), they depend on how the particles of broken debris are laying after you broke a block, or how much you have of it, but there is always an exact correct way of doing the puzzle, which works everytime, unlike trying different methods and expecting more positive or negative results. But it's good the game gives you an option to solve a puzzle sometimes in a  way that feels like kinda cheating, because of how you used your tools, like it was not how it was supposed to be, but this happens very rarely, or making it seem harder than it is, by doing the puzzle in a wrong way.

The game also has a [b]system of skills[/b] that you can level up to increase the effectivness of your tools and HP, making you have more effective tools, more life and life-regen. You also have an optional customization for your tools, like a different kind of block, javelin, drill or sword. You can find the designs for these all over the game in optional areas, where you need to solve the stage puzzle to unlock them, it gives more variety to the game. You also have an option to teleport between beacons you unlocked, to not having to run from one point of the map to another, and be sure to use your save.

Overall the game is not that hard, but quite challenging in it's aspects ( bosses and puzzles). After beating the game you have an option to get a [b]secret achievement[/b] by defeating all bosses, one after another, in their strongest form, without replenishing your HP between battles, and it counts the time you have spent doing it, so you can make a record. This mode is called the Astra Rush.

Also the game features [b]workshop[/b], and you can play workshop maps that other users made and solve their puzzles, or just to unlock some achievements that in main game require some luck to unlock. Or you can just create your own puzzle stages, the game has a special mode for that.

I really enjoyed playing the game, so I totally recommend this, and unlocking all achievements in normal pace takes about 15-20h, which makes it good for completionists.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095938930', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1032, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1032, 'last_played': 1514972287}
review:
Alright, the only reason I bought this game was because it was made by GameFreak. I thought that since GameFreak has gotten a bit of freedom from Nintendo(I think?), maybe they can make other great games other than Pokemon. And since this peaked my interest more than that other game they made with an elephant, I decided to try it out. 

And it's pretty ok, I think. It ain't great but not bad either. The concept of being able to destroy and manipulate debris is pretty cool, I just think it should had more options on what you can create with the debris. The physics in this game isn't perfect but it works quite well most of the time. Most of the puzzles are ok as well except the ones on the final levels. Those made me infuriated. It didn't helped that the floor is slippery as wax throughout the whole game, which one of my major problem with the game. 

As for the story of the game, it's okay, maybe even great. But that's my opinion on it. I liked light hearted stories with a sense of a dark tone in the background nad vice versa. The main character is up to the usual japanese anime protag in a post-apocalyptic world. One of the supporting characters reminds me of Aikuro Mikisugi from Kill La Kill for some reason. The bosses have great personality, I think. The artstyle is also great to look at. Music is decent enough for a GameFreak game.



Overall, I liked this game even with it's flaws. That being said though, this game is not for everyone's taste. If your like GameFreak, physic-based puzzle platformer, and have a lot of patience, you might want to give it a try. If not, then don't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198297087640', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 2697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1931, 'last_played': 1527416162}
review:
Love this game! Perhaps could have little more action than puzzles, but overall game is on big yes.
I hope will be part 2 or some bigger DLC some day in future... :)

...And those who complain physics are wonky etc. just don't understand that precision matters.
You really need THINK how to solve puzzle-stages rather than smashing randomly terrains, hoping it will allow you move forward (% of beaten first boss in steam achievements clearly proves my words)...
In each stage there is always at least one solution indended by devs, which you need to find.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976788157', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 891, 'last_played': 1527355514}
review:
What I like:
Challenging and rewarding boss battles
The game's character development
The game's humor
Puzzles are fun
Killing is bad, m'kay?

What I dislike:
Sometimes the game will ghost your debris into the center of terrain blocks, making your precious debris inaccessible, especially if throwing javelins into walls at close range.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123548365', 'num_games_owned': 249, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1513483362}
review:
I liked this game, though it's certainly not without its flaws.

The concept sounded cool, and the game definitely has a cool visual style, particularly the CG story illustrations and the boss designs -- a bit reminiscent of huke's work on Black Rock Shooter. There's also a great ambient-electronic soundtrack. The meat of the game though is the puzzles, and for the most part the game plays pretty well. The puzzles have a good amount of variation, including a few particularly good ones near the end where the solution is not at all obvious at first.

The game's biggest problem however lies in the physics. Simply put, they're not always predictable. This isn't a problem most of the time, but when you mess up the same puzzle three times in a row because something tipped over in the wrong direction, it can be a bit frustrating. Thankfully dying or resetting a puzzle only sets you back to the start of that puzzle, but it's still not ideal. Also, the English translation is awkward and stilted at best, lending even the human characters a very robotic feel. This makes scenes that seem like they're supposed to be dramatic or funny come off as simply unremarkable.

Recommended if you like puzzle platform games and can deal with a bit of frustration at the physics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050770427', 'num_games_owned': 1189, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1513772490}
review:
For a physics-based puzzle platformer the physics is really wonky. I don't really recommend this game except if you are a tryhard or a masochist. 

I do think some level aren't playtested thoroughly since most of my solutions felt like i'm brute forcing my way to complete it. Where if i do it "normally" the physics engine will do something funky and throw the debris all over the screen.

4/10 would not recommend except if you really are a masochist. 

(I'm looking for fun in games. Ridiculously retrying over and over and over again because some sh*t physics won't let me do x is not fun)

author: {'steamid': '76561198153357443', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1100, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1100, 'last_played': 1498235562}
review:
[strike]I saw that Game Freak made this game, and that was enough of a guarantee to convince me to buy it. Unlike their more popular Pokemon RPGs however, Giga Wrecker is a physics-based puzzle platformer. I played through the whole game and even challenged the boss rush mode on the day it was added, and enjoyed the experience the whole way through. I can safely say that more people need to know about this game, because as it stands it is criminally underrated. The soundtrack is one of my favorites and the gameplay had me hooked from the start. The translation job wasn't the best I've seen, but the puzzles and boss fights were more than enough to outweigh the few issues I had with the translation. Overall, I'd say that this game is well worth buying.[/strike]

Edit: I'm so glad the Pokemon community doesn't know this game exists since the people in that community currently complaining about the Gen 9 games' lack of polish would probably review-bomb it for the crime of having been made by Game Freak. After years of thinking about it and having a more favorable experience with Hollow Knight than when I wrote the original review, I have to admit the game isn't as amazing as I originally hyped it up as, certainly not as good as Hollow Knight ended up being. Still, the game itself is fine. Not amazing, but not so bad that it should be avoided. I would recommend getting the Switch version if you want to try it out, since that version of the game has a better translation and more story content.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039529987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 720, 'last_played': 1487972618}
review:
For some reason i thought that this is more about beat'em'up rpg when i bought the game, but it turned out different. Well i was pleasantly surprised.

This is the most lovely crafted puzzle-platformer I've seen for a long time. Modern look on puzzles gently mixed with metroidvania-like gameplay and old school bosses. And all this is flavored with not bad at all story and characters for this kind of game. I was actually pretty interested in this small setting, despite the fact that i usually pay much less attention to story than a gameplay.

Summing up, I'd like to tell that this game feels like, you know, the game. It gives you a warm, slightly tingling feelings, like when you exited for new challenges, feel like you actually doing something. And it never upsets you even if you fail often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059918308', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 669, 'last_played': 1511638816}
review:
This game...

The core mechanics make it seem like it has so much potential, but for a puzzle game where the physics are the most important mechanic... the physics are really wonky... You could do something practically the same way 3 times and get 3 different results... That just isn't ok.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028210515', 'num_games_owned': 4742, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2622, 'last_played': 1561612129}
review:
Giga Wrecker Ã© um game de aÃ§Ã£o, aventura e puzzle em plataforma 2D o qual retrata um mundo pÃ³s-apocalÃ­ptico governado por robÃ´s que desejam exterminar a raÃ§a humana.

VocÃª joga como Reika, uma garota aparentemente adolescente que quase morre e Ã© salva por um cientista que a transforma em um ciborgue com um braÃ§o biÃ´nico capaz de controlar detritos por meio de um dispositivo. Utilizando seus novos poderes, Reika luta contra robÃ´s e resolve puzzles para salvar o planeta Terra, que estÃ¡ em ruÃ­nas.

O segredo da mecÃ¢nica do game estÃ¡ na habilidade da personagem de controlar e coletar detritos de escombros dos restos de seus inimigos ou do cenÃ¡rio. VocÃª ataca um robÃ´ pequeno, pega os seus detritos e os utiliza para destruir um inimigo um pouco maior. EntÃ£o com os restos desse inimigo, vocÃª acumula uma esfera maior de detritos e a utiliza para derrotar robÃ´s ainda maiores. Isso sem contar que com os detritos, vocÃª pode criar cubos que servem como pesos e plataformas, criar lanÃ§as de detritos para acertar inimigos Ã  distÃ¢ncia ou como suportes que se fixam em paredes, e ainda pode criar uma broca perfuratriz.

As fases do game sÃ£o separadas em 5 Ã¡reas que Ã  medida que sÃ£o desbloqueadas, podem ser exploradas livremente e cada Ã¡rea possui o seu "chefÃ£o". As batalhas nÃ£o sÃ£o fÃ¡ceis, mas depois de vÃ¡rias falhas e tentativas, vocÃª aprende a mecÃ¢nica do oponente e o vence sem muitas dificuldades. Para facilitar para o jogador, orbs que salvam o progresso do jogo estÃ£o convenientemente localizados em pontos crÃ­ticos, como prÃ³ximos aos portais dos chefÃµes.

Giga Wrecker possui uma Ã¡rvore de habilidades. Quando inimigos ou certos blocos sÃ£o destruidos, eles deixam cair cristais. Para cada 100 cristais vocÃª recebe 1 ponto de habilidade para usar na Ã¡rvore de habilidades (que Ã© enorme) e aumentar a sua barra de vida ou a taxa de regeneraÃ§Ã£o dela, alÃ©m de vÃ¡rios upgrades em suas armas e poderes.

Os puzzles comeÃ§am bem simples e com o decorrer do game, podem ficar muito mais desafiadores. Eles dependem bastante da "fÃ­sica" e algumas vezes poderÃ£o resultar em momentos de grande frustraÃ§Ã£o apÃ³s vÃ¡rias tentativas sem Ãªxito.

A direÃ§Ã£o de arte Ã© original e bonita. Tudo parece ter sido desenhado Ã  mÃ£o e o design de cada personagem Ã© autÃªntico e estiloso.

A trilha sonora Ã© tambÃ©m muito boa e certamente ajuda a dar vida a cada momento e emoÃ§Ã£o que o jogo quer expressar.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985250097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 939, 'last_played': 1534623109}
review: From inconsistent physics to touchy controls, I can only recommend that GameFreak stick to Pokemon games. While the concept is good and the art direction is unique, the mechanics of the game suffer from the above mentioned problems. Puzzles appear to be simple in nature but the unpolished controls and RNG physics make things an unwelcomed challenge. Many puzzles that let you access multiple doors or buttons should have check points built in so if you die to one of the many spike pits, you do not have to restart the entire puzzle. I tried really hard to like the game, but find myself wishing I returned it as I get further into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008264709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1445, 'last_played': 1499040813}
review:
Really good. It's got that satisfying kind of frustrated that makes you want to play more.

There are definitely points for improvement and it could be longer, but it's worth the money. I'd like to see more games like this. Concept would make a very interesting competitive online game (looking at you devs).

Note: it's more of a physics puzzle game than a Megaman type platformer. I was expecting the latter and got the former, but was very satisfied regardless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072124799', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 827, 'last_played': 1509303133}
review:
Giga Wrecker was a game that I was unsure if I would like. I found it from a YouTube video, posted by Gellot, of him/her beating all the bosses without taking damage. I was intrigued by the game mechanics and bosses, so I picked up a copy. It was an amazing use of $20.

Pros
-Good and interesting story
-Responsive controls, feels good to use them
-Not too hard, but also not too easy
-Good gameplay
-Great art style
-Custom levels
-Amazing music

Cons
-Sometimes gets random lag spikes
-On occasion, the physics in puzzles needs to be extremely precise
-Some animations are weird


Overall, Giga Wrecker is a great yet horribly underrated game. It needs more love than it currently gets. The bosses are great, the story is great, this entire game is great.The sad thing is that most people expect or only know of Pokemon from Game Freak. Stuff they make on their own just don't seem to get that much attention, which is a shame. All in all, I give this game an 8.5/10. It is something that I would 100% reccomend to my friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059838242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1054, 'last_played': 1507580288}
review:
De la compaÃ±Ã­a que solo sabe hacer juegos de PokÃ©mon, llega un juego que no es de PokÃ©mon. Para un editor tan grande como GF es sorprendente el discreto silencio con el que GIGA WRECKER ha pasado, ni siquiera sabrÃ­a que existe si no me hubiera salido de casualidad en mi lista de descubrimientos.
El juego aÃ±ade mecÃ¡nicas entretenidas al clÃ¡sico plataformer y posee un estilo visual muy atractivo y extravagante, especialmente para los diseÃ±os de los pocos personajes con diÃ¡logos. Los puzzles a veces si cuestan un poco de paciencia o incluso suerte (algunos solo los pude pasar por "aprovechar el bug"). Por otro lado las bossfights, aunque al principio te pegan una arrastrada, son fÃ¡ciles una vez que decifras la secuencia de ataques, cosa comÃºn en el gÃ©nero para ser honesto. Tristemente la campaÃ±a en sÃ­ no tiene mucho valor de rejugabilidad, pero aÃºn entonces incluye un modo de juego donde puedes crear, compartir y descargar niveles creados por la comunidad muy a la Mario Maker.

Al final le darÃ­a un 8, por $180MXN vale la pena y si lo compras en rebaja es una oferta muy buena para las casi 20 horas de juego que tendrÃ¡s hasta obtener todos los logros. AdemÃ¡s me llevÃ© una grata sorpresa cuando varios meses despuÃ©s de que lo comprÃ© le aÃ±adieron un nivel mÃ¡s donde puedes luchar contra todos los bosses uno tras otro pero con un poco mÃ¡s de dificultad, es bonito y raro para nuestros tiempos que un desarrollador aÃ±ada algo a su juego sin cobrar otros $5USD.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004660544', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 699, 'last_played': 1506933274}
review:
Generally fun game, if a bit on the simple end of things for a puzzle platformer, even with a physics puzzle bent. The vast majority of the game is straightforward enough in regards to figuring out the solutions, and there was only ever one time I became stuck.

While there's nothing overly complex about this game, it plays well, the platforming is quite solid (although perhaps a bit too reliant on the instant death spikes towards the end) and the bosses while were fun and distinct.

The story and characters are a bit on the flat side unfortunately, and there are a lot of odd localization choices for the translation, which leaves some bits reading awkwardly (but understandably). It's fun for what it is, and honestly the aesthetics of everything carry it through where the story and characters fail. Game is gorgeous, can't argue that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142011295', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1489480391}
review: An oddly enticing puzzle game, it has very good game feel and suprisingly unique puzzles. The only downside is that you can screw yourself out of puzzles, which is why there's a rewind mechanic. And even that's a streach since by designing them were they can have fail states gives it the ability to have unique puzzles and combat senarios. Plus it has a level editor so you can have infinite levels to pick from .

author: {'steamid': '76561197979881682', 'num_games_owned': 2017, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 905, 'last_played': 1503167774}
review:
Game is an abandonware on PC and it was state officially that PC version WILL NOT receive a console exclusive ALT. version content. Basically, scumbag devs used us, PC gamers, as guinea pigs for their experimental game and after it became a success - jumped in bed with consoles with their shitty exclusivity.

==========

Recommend but with heavy caveats.
First things first - it's a physics based puzzle platformer, not an action game. Don't be fooled by the action-esque aesthetics.
Gameplay is fun and reasonably challenging, art is fantastic when it comes to stages and NPCs, and beyond fantastic when it comes to main characters, CGs and backgrounds. Seriously, CG and protagonists/bosses sprites can put many AAA games to shame. Story is interesting but is a bit cliche (you're going to predict all beats and twists an hour before they come, let alone revealed).
The only 2 negatives: it's a physics based puzzle platformer with all problems that entails: solutions are quite wonky and imprecise, you can get screwed up by your action missing by the couple pixels or milliseconds, or by just straight up RNG. Second negative - it seems that art and music is where lion share of dev effort was put in while actual coding was done by either B-team or people who didn't make any 2D platformers before. Game has some collision detection issues, some occasional performance problems and extremely wonky physics.

Overall game is great but you might get mildly(/extremely) infuriated during some of its parts.

P.S. Someone on the team had an "ingenious" (<- notice the sarcasm) idea to map "interact" to â†‘ button so if you're playing on the controller - get used to a lot accidental interactions. Oh, btw, did i mention that the "reset puzzle even if you've just solved it after spending 10+ min" objects in game do their function immediately upon interaction, without showing a confirmation prompt? Yep, have fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133660957', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3654, 'last_played': 1562714620}
review:
Franchement, j'ai adorÃ© ce jeu, qui est assez prenant, sans durer trop longtemps pour lasser (une quinzaine d'heures). Le systÃ¨me de ce jeu de plate-forme a osÃ© des originalitÃ©s, qui constittuent la base mÃªme de son concept, et qui mÃ©ritent Ã  elles seules de l'essayer. Vous acquÃ©rirez progressivement des compÃ©tences, et celles-ci vous permettront d'utiliser les Ã©lÃ©ments de dÃ©cor (les dÃ©combres du titre) comme Ã©lÃ©ments fondamentaux pour progresser. Car vous devez vous-mÃªme modifier le dÃ©cor (et pas seulement le dÃ©molir) pour progresser dans les niveaux, et revenir dans le temps si vous avez ratÃ© quelque chose. Un peu comme un puzzle-game. Le concept aurait pu Ãªtre davantage poussÃ©, mais l'expÃ©riencen' en demeure pas moins intÃ©ressante.
Car Ã  cÃ´tÃ© de son originalitÃ© de gameplay, il faut bien garder en tÃªte que Giga Wrecker est un jeu indÃ©pendant, avec ses dÃ©fauts et ses qualitÃ©s.
Au rang des dÃ©fauts, rapidement: des collisions avec les Ã©lÃ©ments de dÃ©cors pas toujours logiques (on passe au travers de certains Ã©lÃ©ments et pas d'autres) et frustrantes, mais tempÃ©rÃ©es par la dimension "die and retry". Des Ã©crans parfois trop austÃ¨res (skill ou carte). Et certaines habiletÃ©s qui n'apportent qu'un intÃ©rÃªt esthÃ©tique Ã  l'histoire (notamment les nombreuses "arche abilities", qui auraient pu par exemple apporter d'avantage de petits bonus tactiques selon les variantes).
Parce qu'au niveau de l'esthÃ©tique, on rentre vraiment dans un travail soignÃ©, pour un petit jeu. L'univers tout entier baigne dans un design post-apo/futuriste assez original, vraiment trÃ¨s rÃ©ussi et cohÃ©rent. Les tableaux narratifs, quoique fixes, sont vraiment des oeuvres d'art, totalement raccords avec le reste, tout en appuyant la personnalitÃ© des personnages (nous y reviendront). Les musiques, malgrÃ© des boucles parfois un peu courtes, sont vraiment trÃ¨s belles, et alternent toujours au bon moment les passages contemplatifs, lyriques, ou la violence des affrontement. Et les affrontements avec les boss, qui constituent l'enjeu de l'histoire, sont certes assez dirigistes, avec des patterns Ã  comprendre pour triompher, mais bien personnalisÃ©s et prÃ©cis.
Surtout, l'histoire et les personnages sont vraiment bien menÃ©s, avec une psychologie trÃ¨s construite, et une Ã©volution progressive du personnage principal, qui change progressivement sa vision du monde, avec une petite nuance de "QuÃ¨te initiatique" toujours trÃ¨s sympa. Et d'une maniÃ¨re gÃ©nÃ©rale, au fil des bulles de dialogues, la personnalitÃ© des personnages, Y COMPRIS DES BOSS (qui ne sont pas lÃ  juste pour se faire exterminer), est prÃ©cisÃ©e par petites touches. Sans spoiler, l'histoire, qui commence d'une faÃ§on des plus classiques, sans Ãªtre une rÃ©volution, est trÃ¨s bien menÃ©e, et d'une profondeur et une subtilitÃ© inattendues au dÃ©part.
Au final, si j'ai trouvÃ© le systÃ¨me de jeu trÃ¨s sympa quoique perfectible, je suis tombÃ© amoureux de tous les Ã -cÃ´tÃ©: les designs, les musiques, les personnages, l'univers. J'espÃ¨re sincÃ¨rement qu'une suite sera donnÃ©e Ã  cet opus, en en conservant le niveau d'exigence et en en amÃ©liorant les quelques dÃ©fauts.

review: You literally can't play any part of the first fifteen minutes of this game for more than 90 seconds in a row before it will interrupt you with another tedious, boring conversation between forgettable characters mumbling expository dialog. If the gameplay was fun I'd tough it out, but it's not. It's just kinda...there. Don't waste your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995017516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1500673248}
review:
I really wanted to like this game, but due to some flaws I can't really reccomend it, especially at full price.

First off, this game is much more of a puzzle game than a platformer, at least the portions I was able to get through. So if you are expecting a platformer with puzzle elements (e.g. Trine) you will be dissapointed.

Pros:
Good graphics
Creative Design

Cons:
Disjointed - The different sections of the game don't really mesh well. This is particularly evident in the boss fights, when the game abruptly changes from "go your own pace" puzzles to "frantic timing"
Unpolished:
Both the translation and design seem rushed.
Some areas have no music, with no particular reason why there shouldn't be any. 
Checkpoints are not automatic, so if you forget to activate one you get sent back several screens upon death. 
Sometimes puzzles solutions don't work because a piece of debris gets stuck somewhere. This has caused me to reject correct solutions at least once, possibly twice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198155592702', 'num_games_owned': 1094, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1035, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 823, 'last_played': 1537126110}
review:
Giga Wrecker, ein sehr sehr tolles Spiel.

Seit langem nicht mehr haben mich die Spielwelt und die Charaktere eines Spiels so begeistert. Und genau darin liegt in meinen Augen auch die StÃ¤rke dieses Spiels. Es sieht unfassbar gut aus, die Charakter-, Gegner- und Boss-Designs sind ungaublich gut durchdacht ebenso wie das Design der gesamten Welt.
Man kommt zwar ca. in der Mitte des Spiels wieder in die Anfangswelt zurÃ¼ck und die 3 zuvor erkundete Welten, die nur zur HÃ¤lfte frei waren, werden nun auch komplett frei. Trotzdem fÃ¼hlen sich die Level immernoch frisch an.

Das Gameplay macht wirklich sehr SpaÃŸ. Ein 2D-Plattformer mit vielen Puzzels. Es kommen immer wieder neue Elemente hinzu, damit die Puzzel nicht fad werde. Jedoch merkte ich bei mir, wie ich gegen Ende hin durch das viele Neustarten und Neuversuchen der Level langsam echt genervt geworden bin, da ich nicht mehr mein Gehirn benutzen wollte, sondern viel lieber den nÃ¤chsten Storyhappen bekommen oder mich Ã¼ber den nÃ¤chsten Boss freuen wollte.

Der Soundtrack ist solide, teilweise hat es mich schon etwas gecatcht, jedoch nichts atemberaubendes. Den Soundtrack DLC werde ich mir persÃ¶nlich also nicht kaufen, aber ich hab mich jetzt auch nicht allzu sehr auf die Hintergrundmusik konzentriert. Vielleicht ist sie an mir auch einfach vorbei gegangen.


Alles in allem kann ich das Spiel nur aus reinstem Herzen empfehlen und Game Freak danken, dass sie ihr wunderschÃ¶nes Spiel auch auf den PC gebracht haben, da ich sonst auf jeden Fall nichts davon mitbekommen hÃ¤tte. Ihr habt mit Giga Wrecker einen verdienten Platz in dem Favoriten Ordner meiner Steam Bibliothek. :3

author: {'steamid': '76561197966370322', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1500497838}
review:
I seriously don't see how this game can get a positive score. Yes, the graphics are certainly not bad, nor is the soundtrack but the controls are kinda wonky and it suffers from some old school game design in the form of ridiculous spiky death traps and obnoxious knockback. Still, not that much of a problem if you've suffered through the NES era.

However what well and truly kills the game and makes me want to throw my controller through the screen in rage is the physics based puzzles. For instance, in some places you need to guide a wall bouncing laser to hit a certain spot. The physics mean you have potentially hundreds of variables to take into account and in many cases it comes down to pure RNG if you get it right or not. Did your block fall in right angle? Did the destructible surroundings settle in the proper manner?

I quite frankly want my money back.

author: {'steamid': '76561198273914721', 'num_games_owned': 48, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1540075087}

author: {'steamid': '76561198138098072', 'num_games_owned': 321, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 1387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 857, 'last_played': 1561673455}
review:
Recomendo muito esse jogo.

- Ã“tima jogabilidade.
- A histÃ³ria Ã© um pouco confusa, mas bem envolvente (pra mim pelo menos):
[spoiler]Ã‰ uma histÃ³ria pÃ³s-apocaliptica onde mÃ¡quinas conhecidas como Ajeets estÃ£o destruindo e escravizando a raÃ§a humana. Por possuir uma histÃ³ria com base em "Time Travel"(que vocÃª sÃ³ descobre que Ã© baseado em Time Travel la pro meio do jogo), ela Ã© bem confusa e nÃ£o faz muito sentido. Como a personagem principal pode lembrar das coisas que aconteceram no futuro, quando uma outra personagem volta pro passado?[/spoiler]
- Os puzzles sÃ£o interessantes, as mecÃ¢nicas do jogo tambÃ©m. Conforme vocÃª faz progresso no jogo, vocÃª libera diferentes habilidades que utilizam os detritos que vocÃª consegue controlar, e vocÃª os utiliza para resolver os quebra-cabeÃ§as do jogo, e atÃ© mesmo a enfrentar alguns inimigos.
- O jogo nÃ£o Ã© muito difÃ­cil.
- Os upgrades do jogo sÃ£o pouco diversificados, a maioria sÃ£o upgrades para aumentar sua energia e a regeneraÃ§Ã£o de energia.
- As personagens sÃ£o pouco desenvolvidas, mas para a histÃ³ria do jogo, faz sentido nÃ£o existir um aprofundamento das personagens.
- A trilha sonora Ã© gostosinha. Da pra ficar ouvindo por horas tranquilo.

Existem algumas poucas coisinhas que me deixam incomodado no jogo. Coisa boba. Por exemplo, o sprite das personagens (Sprite = Imagem que representa a personagem), quando vocÃª vira de um lado pro outro, Ã© sÃ³ uma imagem "flipada", invertida. Ou seja, o braÃ§o direito de uma personagem, por exemplo, quando ela vira para o outro lado, vira o braÃ§o esquerdo dela. Como jÃ¡ disse, Ã© algo bobo, mas me imcomoda.

NÃ£o Ã© perfeito, mas vale a pena jogar. Daria uns 8, ou 8.5 de 10 se fosse pra "classificar" com nota. Mas nota Ã© sÃ³ um nÃºmero. Ã‰ sempre bom jogar o jogo pra saber se vocÃª realmente vai gostar ou nÃ£o. NinguÃ©m melhor pra dizer se um jogo vale a pena jogar do que vocÃª mesmo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075220579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1499196231}
review:
A very neat approach to a Puzzle/Platformer made by Game Freak.
The game runs flawlessly, I haven't run into any sort of lag, nor has my game crashed once.


A lot of people note that, the flaw Giga Wrecker runs into, has something to do with the physics engine being wonky and collision detection often not doing its part.
[b]I have barely come across any of this.[/b] Only 1 or 2 times have I fallen through something (lose debris), me being at fault for trying to jump on something on a very weird angle. 
The Physics Engine is very consistent and never made any problems either.

The game gives off a lack of polish due to it starting very fast, the tutorial area is rather short and you are being thrown into action rather quickly. This "lack of polish", however, is later barely noticable.


Giga Wrecker starts of rather easy, but later changes to a somewhat moderate challenge, never have I felt that something was impossible or just too hard. 

Also, Giga Wrecker is [b]BEAUTIFUL[/b].
The art style is one of a kind and pretty much made me buy this game in the first place.

I recommend this game a whole lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132687566', 'num_games_owned': 313, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1701, 'last_played': 1652407467}
review: I can't put into words how much I love this game. It looks amazing, the puzzles and boss fights are challenging enough to give you a feeling of fufillment when triumphed, dialogue (while a bit off in some places, but not too bad) is pretty great, the enemy designs are just plain rad [spoiler](especially Astra Sarama)[/spoiler], and that's just scratching the surface. I would gladly play through this game over and over again. I'm just a sucker for good boss fights and puzzles and this game does way more than deliver on that end. I'm in the middle of another playthrough as I write this as well. I should get back to it. This game gets my two thumbs up and a 9/10 from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012992323', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 668, 'last_played': 1496951215}
review:
Let's start with positives.  The game's art style is really fantastic, to say the least.  A nice, 'chunky' visual aesthetic.  The open-ended approach to puzzle platforming is refreshing, and very well thought-out.  Honestly, taken from a step back, the game is refreshing to play, and I wish there was more creativity like Giga Wrecker's in modern gaming mechanics.

To quickly summarize what the game lacks.. It feels very quickly pushed out.  The physics of movement feels a little lacking; sometimes you fall through what appear to be solid surfaces.  Sometimes, in the vein of classic side-scrolling action platformers, you take one hit, which causes you to bounce into a second enemy or stage hazard (most notably and egregiously in the Astra fights).  And sometimes, the physics engine just straight-up disagrees with you.  All three of the above will generally result in death, especially in the latter half of the game, with the oft usage of spikes and pitfalls. 
Because of the relatively quick loading times, it's not as much of an issue as it could be, but because of the nature of some rooms, you're forced to repeat several sections before you can get back to the segment that caused your death.. only to die to it again because of one of the above, or when you accidentally push the reset button for a fraction of a second.

The music's lacking, and the localization's even moreso.  It's exciting to see Game Freak's name on something considering how much of a mainstay it is regarding my childhood memories regarding the pokemon franchise, so that's what caused me to gravitate towards the game, and, I think, in a lot of cases, it's the same for most of the people who ended up picking Giga Wrecker up.  But genuinely, someone really need to go through these sorts of games with a fine comb before they get pushed out.  I was expecting more, especially after grasping just how intuitive and clever the game's core mechanics are.  Please, make more games like this, but treat them with kid gloves next time, okay?  This sort of result is just not acceptable.

review: good game! very pretty, very fun. Puzzles were challenging but not frustrating because of confusion, but because you have to make the physics work for you sometimes. It can take some throwing things at the wall until something sticks. But the combat and boss battles were awesome as hell, and the music and story were also pretty rad. 8/10! Don't pass this up if it's on sale!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031654661', 'num_games_owned': 3513, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 800, 'last_played': 1528050716}
review:
Giga Wrecker is a game I bought after someone mentioned that it was made by Game Freak. I didn't even look at the gameplay as I wanted to be surprised and I definitely was not expecting one of the best puzzle platformers i've played in some time.

The main gimmick to this game is finding debris and combining it into a large ball of debris that you carry around. You can use this to extend your attack range, make platforms and more as you get new upgrades. Each area you visit has its own mechanics for puzzles, like making your debris balls bouncy or poison gas that lifts platforms as well as a new power in each area to use which makes them all stand out. There is also a skill tree in this game which I feel can increase the replayability, as I went through the whole game without knowing about a skill that can make more platforms.

The best part in this game are the physics and how you use your abilites to affect them. There is a lot of satisfaction when you solve puzzles in this game and it's a lot of fun to see the blocks fall in the exact places you need them to. There are also multiple ways to solve certain puzzles, and in a lot of places I felt like I was breaking the game. The combat is pretty simple, but I don't think this was the focus of the game, and a lot of the time combat is about finding enough debris in the level to attack them. The boss fights are pretty great as they still use the main mechanic of the game, and learning the patterns of the boss is fun and satisfying.

The graphics are unique and look nice. The sprites themselves are very detailed, and the art used in story sequences look lovely. The story is pretty interesting but it is one of the weaker elements of the game because of the bad translation. You can understand what is being said most of the time, but a lot of it sounds strange. Finally, the music is excellent - in the main areas it's nice and relaxing for puzzle solving. It gets a bit more intense during the boss fights.

This review is kind of a mess but I hope it gets more people interested in this game, as I feel like it's a bit underrated right now. A few final notes are that my computer is not that great so the game's performance was slow at times, but the game was good enough that I kept with it. I'm also planning on getting more playtime out of it through the game's custom levels made by other people.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025141755', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1698, 'last_played': 1561693590}
review:
This game was a ton of fun. It's challenging enough to always stay engaging, but rarely frustrating. And the game often doesn't force you to solve the puzzles in a certain way. I know there were a few puzzles that I did not solve the intended way.
It's really also beautiful. I want to take every cutscene image set it as my wallpaper.

There were a few issues I had with it though.
-It's pretty short, and while you can get make and get custom levels from the workshop, there are only a few dozen of them, most of which aren't very interesting.
-The collision physics needs some work. It's way too easy to accidentally fall through an object you didn't mean to, right onto some instadeath spikes.
-You get several powerful abilities, but they're mostly just for platforming and puzzle solving. Even though you can buy skills to let you use them in combat, there's never really a reason to do so, especially against the bosses. Speaking of which...
-The difficulty progression is off. The first boss was a huge challenge, and I died a ton of times before I got the hang of it. But I beat the final boss on my first try, and the last few before that went pretty easily as well. I'm sure part of it was that I didn't know what I was doing as well with the first boss, but I think that more of it was that I was just too powerful by the time I got to the final boss. Against the first boss, you have to avoid pretty much every attack if you want to survive. But by the time you get to the last few bosses, you have a lot more health and you'll be able to heal damage as fast as they can deal it without even really trying.
-The story/writing isn't very engaging. Maybe it's better in Japanese, but the translation really isn't very good.
-The art during the levels always seems a bit odd since the player and the enemies are so much more detailed than everything around them.

But despite my complaints, I do think the game was a lot of fun. I might not ever pick it back up, but I don't regret the time I invested into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981620225', 'num_games_owned': 1630, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 871, 'last_played': 1496012101}
review:
I play a lot of 2D platformers, and this is one of the best I've played in recent years. It leans heavily on the standard Metroidvania framework, but the puzzles and abilities you acquire really make it feel like something fresh and unique. The art is great, the boss fights are satisfyingly difficult until you figure out their patterns, and the puzzles are often difficult enough to make you feel accomplished when you solve them without being so difficult or abstract that you run screaming for an FAQ. I could go on, but I think you get the point: there's a lot to like here.

Unfortunately, there are also a few things to be aware of going into it that might affect your enjoyment. First, the English translation is a mess. It's never so bad that you can't understand what they're trying to say, but it's obvious that non-native speakers translated it and the dude listed on the credits as "Translation QA" didn't actually "A" the "Q," which is especially strange given that the game came out in early access initially, so there was plenty of time to have those errors pointed out. If you're like me and grew up in the NES days, when broken English was the standard in video game translations, or if you don't care that much about these things, it's not probably a deal-breaker.

More frustrating was that sometimes--seemingly due to debris being at odd angles--I would land solidly on a platform, but I would just fall through it as if it wasn't something I could stand on or that I'd missed the platform. It didn't come up very often, but most of the times it did, the "non-platform" was over spikes or a bottomless pit. Even though it was rare, the somewhat finicky platforms are something to be aware of.

Overall, though, this was a great game, and the fact it isn't being talked about more is a shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963963585', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1495330289}
review:
<1 Hour Later>

- The localization is painful, the words can read but it takes some used to
- Some of the hitboxes/colliders don't react predictably, sometimes registering a "hit" with the player for no apparent reason and others missing it entirely 
- The soundtrack is really mellow, which if the combat element didn't feature so prominently would be much more fitting
- The physics component is well done for the most part, although I've already experienced issues where the direction I'm facing influences the speed of certain objects making precise positioning needlessly difficult
- The exposition dump is really condensed and jumps straight into terms and structure unique to the game world rather than slowly introducing you to one element at a time and building it up. It reads likea list of bullet points being read to you by someone offscreen

It feels like an attempt at a mix of Kill La Kill, Megaman and a physics based platformer, and so far it's reasonably successful. However the game mechanics and script don't seem to mesh as cleanly as they should for me.

<1.1 Hours Later>

Just ALT-F4'd.
There's no reason that the camera cannot follow the character and keep a functional distance at all times. After realizing that I had neglected to go to a save point (which considering the open world feel and that this game does not appear to be attempting to be a rogue-like makes NO sense) I died because the camera got up close to the character and didn't show me that there was an enemy directly below me. I dropped down and got juggled to death. There are "zones" or areas of the map that will cause the camera to draw closer or farther away from the character, and since the camera isn't locked to the character's horizontal movement this actually becomes nauseating. 

This basic design flaw both questions and answers so much about Game Freak.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091304696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1495168100}
review:
Ugh, This game looked so fun. And when it got a good sale, I was pretty excited to get it. But my excitement deflated pretty quickly. 

The core idea here is interesting, but it's not handled well.  Very simple puzzles are ruined by the chaos of the physics engine. I had to do puzzles several times, in the tutorial section no less, because objects didn't fall right. I loathe to think of how frustrating the future puzzles would be.

It's surprising how much the characters talk, and yet how little they actually say. The music was... passable, I suppose. And, the art is nice. That's about the one thing they got right. If they got a better writer, this would be a cool anime, maybe. Pretty boring game, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007905809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 991, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 951, 'last_played': 1533958456}
review:
One of the most fuffilling Metroidvania games that we sorely needed

Portal meets Megaman meets Metroid/Castlevania

Challenging gameplay and puzzles, Bosses are strong as hell if you love more old school games that are both fun and challenging this games for you.


Graphics 8/10  good just some backgrounds can be distracting. enemy designs are cool some remind me of a mix between sonic and megaman 

Gamplay 9/10 fun challeging some puzzles and bosses may be furstrating but are satisfying when you figure them out. the level editor makes the games replay value almost infinite if people keep adding to it. 

Story 7/10 I really love the story and mystery of the world the plot iself is rather simple but still solid and engaging However the ending feels a bit lack luster without spoiling to much it left a lot open, and unresolved. prehaps they plan on making a sequal 

Sound/music 6/10 sound effects are nice some of the music is good but nothing to gush over. some music can get repetitive

author: {'steamid': '76561197972364092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 1526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1081, 'last_played': 1499106966}
review:
Giga Wrecker is a 2D action puzzle platformer. You play as a young girl called Reika, who has been transformed into a cyborg and now battles the robots that have successfully defeated mankind. The puzzles consist of box physics, lasers and the ususal spikes and pits. You can destroy or cut parts of the level to solve the puzzles. The action comes from the robots that you encounter in the levels and the bosses you must defeat. Bosses each have their own pattern and stages and take a few tries to learn. The story is told through dialog text during the level and every once in a while there is a still art cut scene.

Graphics and sound are good and I personally quite like the art style. Controls are okay, but can also be remapped if necessary. If you have a different aspect ratio than 16:9 you may get some display artefacts. 1920x1200 has black bars that aren't cleared and show whatever part of the Steam overlay was last drawn over them.

The game offers three save slots and you need to expicitly save at save points dotted around the map. After death the game will however restore you at the last door, teleporter or warp point, so you really never need to reload during play.

I do have a few gripes with the gameplay. The biggest problem is the floaty or slippery platforming. This will get you killed often as Reika will slide off platforms you squarly hit and drop into spikes or into a pit. Wobbly blocks sometimes make this worse. Add to that the knockback and the very short invulnerability after being hit and boss fights quickly turn frustrating. I feel that tighter platforming would have made this game a lot better.

Despite its flaws I do recommend Giga Wrecker. If you can deal with grinding the bosses until you get the pattern (and get better at the game in the process) then you will find a satisfying little platformer that rewards the persistent player.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062404482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 892, 'last_played': 1491864443}
review:
This game definetly deserves more love from the community.

Giga Wrecker is a PC exclusive indie game from GameFreak (you know, the dudes that Nintendo enslaved 20 years ago to do PokÃ¨mon) and god damn is it good.

It's basically a metroid-vania 2D platformer except it's not retro style and has very curious mechanics. To me, it feels like playing a sidescrolling version of Portal since you have to solve puzzles with abilities and such.
The plot is very interesting, sometimes weird and makes you question your motives throughout the game, while you're being carried around by a sweet soundtrack that is very fitting.

The art style is lovely, a bit "edgy" but considering the whole mecha theme it fits perfectly. It's a pity some aspects have been forgotten, like mono-dimensional sprites, but those are just minor things that could've made the game a bit more polished.

It's not a hard game, the mechanics are a bit unforgiving tho.
The platforms are a bit wanky when not 100% horizontal, you get easily punished if you abuse your abilities, sometimes when you get hit you lose track of the character because the backgrounds are very colourful, the knockback is outrageous and 90% of the time makes you fall to your death to bottomless pits or spikes and the absurd amount of debris that comes out from broken objects is a double-edged sword. It can help you solve puzzles in a non conventional way or can completely screw you up (fortunately every puzzle has a reset pad). 

In the end you're always happy after completion and you never feel frustrated after completing a sector. And if you haven't completed it 100% you can go back at whatever point to find unlockables or get achievements.

I highly recommend it if you love the genre and a fluent platformer with a bit of challenge

author: {'steamid': '76561198024619703', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 754, 'last_played': 1489356785}
review:
Each room is basically a puzzle, with a few ways to solve it as you unlock more abilities.

The boss fights are all about timing and countering their techniques, usually requiring you not to get hit at all or you miss your opportunity to strike back.

However there where times were I would fall through a platform that was on an angle, usually resulting in death.

Overall it was a very enjoyable game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008962715', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 885, 'last_played': 1488686592}
review:
Giga Wrecker is a [i][b]very pretty[/b][/i] but very run-of-the-mill puzzle platformer with most everything being forgetable besides the artstyle and boss fights.  7/10 Average for its type, with several nice things.


[u]Graphics:[/u]
I'm going to get the gush out of the way first.  I am severly biased here, as the game's artist, ASGR (aka Asagiri), is one of my top favorite artists in the world and has been for several years. Its no exaggeration to say his art speaks to me. I was downtroden, as over the last year I thought he had dropped off the face of the earth. Low and behold this past February I learned that he had spent that time working on this game.  And hoh boy was it worth it.  I can say I bought this game full price solely for the beautiful artstyle, nothing else included.

So yes, I am very biased in that case, but I tried to look at everything else with a keen eye.

Game looks fantastic at 1080p, everything is drawn very very crisp and there are no upscaling problems; in fact some textures are so high resolution that you get some downscaling pixelation, especially on the player character's sprite when the camera zooms out a lot.  The artstyle is pretty damn strong, and the game screenshots speak for themselves.  The animation is also very fluid and never breaks that artstyle even with its fluidity.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=858914194

Camera is automatically adjusted to provide the best cinematic and puzzle solving experience.  When a puzzle calls for you needing to see the entire area, the camera pans out to do that.  When the game wants you to focus on a specific aspect of the puzzle when you walk into that area, the game does that.  When the game wants to show you some fantastic bit of background to build ambiance, the game does that too!  Its great in those situations, but annoying in others. Sometimes the camera moves unnaturally and too quickly; the panning and zooming when you walk between areas can cause motion sickness, so be wary if you're sensitive to that stuff.

One interesting and unexpected addon to the game are cosmetics for the abilities you gain throughout the game.  Some look awesome, some are nostalgic, and others are just plain funny.  Its a fun addition to the game and definitely helps build some love for it.


[u]Sound:[/u]
Soundtrack is good, but its really repetitive so it might get on your nerves after a while. Given a lot of puzzles take you some time to complete, it won't take you long to realize how short the music loops are.

Sound effects themselves are spot on and really bring the game to life more than you'd think.  I think its the second strongest feature of the game behind the artstyle and presentation itself.

Voice acting is a nice feature and gives personality to various foes you fight, but you'll notice that they resampled quite a few a few voices on the bosses.


[u]Gameplay:[/u]
The game looks amazing, but take away the art and there really isn't much you haven't seen before.

I used an xbox360 controller when playing this game and for the most part it controls fine. Area doors are annoying though, because the same button to attack up is the same button to open a door.

The gameplay boils down to something kind of like a metroidvania and physics puzzle platformer combined, whereas you gain new abilities as you progress through the game and unlock new puzzles with those abilities. Complete more puzzles to progress, and every once in a while there is a boss fight. Unlike a metroidvania the game has next to no optional backtracking, although there are optional areas and puzzles.  There are some RPG elements thrown in that let you upgrade your existing abilities and add on to their capabilities.  An unusual mix of gameplay elements, but again nothing you haven't seen before.

So yeah, ironically the boss fights in this game are better than the core puzzle gameplay. That's my personal opinion, but I felt much less frustration and had a lot more fun on them rather than the puzzles themselves, I explain below.

The Boss fights are the funnest, best designed parts of this game. The major downside to some is that all the boss fights are entirely scripted rather than reactive, so most of the difficulty revolves around timing and memorizing the patterns.  Also, at first many of the boss earlier fight mechanics are never revealed to you until you die several times, at which point the game will give you a necessary hint.  Later boss fights also never tell you that they randomly borrow from the mechanics learned in other boss fights and other parts of the game, so keep an eye out and react instinctually.

More than often not you'll find yourself fighting the physics of the game rather than elegantly using it to your advantage. A lot of puzzles are very frustrating and there were a handful I felt like I had to "cheat" my way through rather than take the intended path (note by cheat I mean complete the puzzle in a way that the developers obviously didn't intend). Another handful of puzzles felt like I only completed them from sheer luck. That hints at some bad puzzle design. You can't stop all the exploits, but when its so unclear how to solve them such that the player resorts to unintentional methods or game exploits to progress, that is a problem.  That said, there were some very fun puzzles as well.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=870228994


[u]Plot / Story / World:[/u]
This is the weakest part of the game.  There are times when you'll feel a twinge for the players as you read their dialogue, but its super super freaking cliche and is on the whole unbelievable, even when you consider it from within its own  ridiculous bubble.  If you have encountered much eastern scifi or post-apocalyptic stuff before ([spoiler]or any time travel[/spoiler]), then you'll see everything coming from a mile off.  The game doesn't try to be anything but simple in nature, but its annoyingly simple and very tropey (and not in a good way).  There is little to no satisfaction (comparably to the other features of the game) in progressing to see the plot unfold, since there is barely any there to sustain the player and what is there is so utterly cliche, predictable, and tropey.

That's not to say the characters aren't interesting; many of the bosses are so cool looking.  All I'm saying is that more than likely most of your love from the characters will come from the character designs and actions taken in battle, rather than the dialogue or plot.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=869510534


[u]Translation:[/u]
Its weak and full of engrish.  You'll get the point of the game and what is going on but it definitely won't sound natural.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047436117', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1130, 'last_played': 1488506875}
review:
Giga Wrecker is a puzzle/plateformer game with an anime art style that take place in a post apocolyptic planet. The character you play as has the ability to manipulate debris from enemies she kills and from rock formations she can destroy. The debris you collect is used as your main weapon and it has increased utility the more you collect. 

To begin with the combat in the game is very simplistic yet satisfying. Your attacks can be used to solve puzzles and destroy enemies. While satisfying the game does have a lack of enemy variety as there are only a handful of enemy types with single move sets. This however is not the main aspect of the game as the puzzles are what make up the core parts of the game. The only area where the combat truly excels is the boss fights. The bosses have multiple movesets and attacks which make them alot of fun to face even if you're not to great at platformers.

The puzzles in the game are quite easy to solve but are unique in their nature do to the debris ability the game gives you. Most of your time in game will be solving these puzzles and trying to find the unfortunately limited amount of collectable items. The puzzles can either be fun to solve or become a nightmare do to the sometimes wonky physics engine. You may very well know the solution to a puzzle but executing it properly is finicky sometimes. 

The game has a leveling system which is very 1-dimensional as the upgrades you get for them are uninspired. These upgrades  range from more health to extra weapon damage and range.

Finally, the game's story is nothing special as it is filled with common tropes and bland characters. I'm not going to go into the specifics as to not spoil anything. The story is atleast entertaining as for most of the game there is an element of mystery. The overall story is soft-hearted with some dark elements thrown in. If I could describe the story's appeal in 1 word, it would be "cute". The character designs also reflect that description. 

Overall I think Giga Wrecker is a fun casual game that you will enjoy if you like cute characters and satisfying puzzle/platformer gameplay. It was enough to entertain me for around 18 hours with screwing around with the level creator and gameplay elements.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141371226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1490420166}
review:
Reminds me so much of the Megaman series, except the puzzles are like 300% harder. Longest i have ever taken was 1 hour and it was the worst and best 1 hour. Would 5/10 do another hard af puzzle.

Of course, this game is nearly perfect, if it wasnt for the fact that the entire game feels like an ice stage. The character sliders across the screen when im trying to balance myself on a pillar.

Boss designs? Absolutely badass. Wish i took a screenshot of the first one but got too engrossed on trying to figure out her patterns... Come to think of it i also forgot to do it with the second one. If any of you kind peeps could get one for me..? Or is there a gallery somewhere?

Soundtrack? Really catchy and endearing. 10/10 would buy the OST once i get the money to do so.

Other complaints other than ice level level movement? Maybe sometimes the screen zooms out way too much but i guess its for visibility so i can't really call that a valid complaint.

Would i recommend it? Yeah sure, go for it! As expected of GAME FREAK, this game is really fun.

[strike]capcom when revive megaman mmmmm?[/strike]

author: {'steamid': '76561198107841643', 'num_games_owned': 614, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 1465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1220, 'last_played': 1491730281}
review:
I'd never expect the developers responsible for Pokemon to create a platformer this good. You would have expected that when developers like this hit big they would bask in their glory and spend their days relaxing and enjoying their fame and millions but noooo, Gamefreak HAD to make their own original game, just so that we could shut our mouths up for thinking that they were licking Nintendo's balls the whole time. And I'm glad they did, since this game turned out absolutely awesome.

Pros:
- Cute and awesome artwork
- Adorable voice effects and music
- Interesting and fun game mechanics
- Challenging; you won't drop this one in a while
- Level editor
- Robot waifus

Cons:
- The art is a bit too sharp for the game; takes some time getting used to
- Default keyboard configurations are messed up, a controller is recommended
- Somewhat awkward english

I believe that this game is 100% worth the money. It is enjoyable for both casual players and hardcore completionists. Good job Gamefreak for not disappointing.

Das Design ist untypisch fÃ¼r ein Cyperpunk Game. Es ist bunt und hat ein typisches Animecharacter-Design. Ich kann allen, die nichts mit damit anfangen kÃ¶nnen, wÃ¤rmstens ans Herz legen es trotzdem mal zu testen.
Das Gameplay ist eine super Mischung aus Puzzle-Plattformer und Actiongame.

Einzig und allein der Skilltree ist mir ein Dorn im Auge. Dieser ist sehr groÃŸ und man "levelt" sich dort sehr schnell hoch. Es gibt kleinere Upgrades, die das Leben erhÃ¶hen und FÃ¤higkeiten mit grÃ¶ÃŸerer Auswirkung. Das Problem hierbei ist, dass unheimlich viel mit AbkÃ¼rzungen gearbeitet wird, die nicht immer klar sind.
